'''''Melanoleuca''''' is a poorly known [[genus (biology)|genus]] of [[saprotrophic]] [[mushrooms]] traditionally classified in the family [[Tricholomataceae]]. Most are small to medium sized, white, brown, ocher or gray with a cylindrical to [[subcylindrical]] [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] and white to pale yellowish [[lamella (mycology)|gills]]. The [[basidiospore]]s are ellipsoid and ornamented with [[amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]] warts.<ref name=Metrod1948/><ref name=Singer1986/><ref name=Bon1991/> ''Melanoleuca'' is considered a difficult group to study due to their macroscopic similarities among [[species (biology)|species]] and the need of a thorough microscopic analysis to separate species.<ref name=Boekhout1988/> [[Nucleic acid sequence|DNA studies]] have determined that this genus is closely related to ''[[Amanita]]'' and ''[[Pluteus]]'' and that it does not belong to the family Tricholomataceae.<ref name=Moncalvo2002/><ref name=Matheny2006/>

==Etymology==

The name of the genus is derived from the [[Ancient Greek]] ''melano-'' meaning "black", and ''leukos'' meaning "white".

==Description==

===Macroscopic characters===
The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] of ''Melanoleuca'' are small to medium size ([[pileus (mycology)|pileus]] 10–120 mm in diameter). The pileus is convex becoming depressed at the center, it is usually dry and white, brown, ocher, or grey. The gills are [[lamella (mycology)|adnexed]], [[lamella (mycology)|sinuate]], [[lamella (mycology)|adnate]], or [[lamella (mycology)|subdecurrent]], white to yellowish. The stipe is central, cylindrical or slightly swollen at the base, dry and longitudinally striate. Development gymnocarpic and stipitocarpic. Odor and taste usually indistinctive, mild, fungoid, sweet, or rancid. The [[spore print]] is white to pale yellowish.<ref name=Singer1986/><ref name=Bon1991/>

===Microscopic characters===
[[File:Cystidia Melanoleuca.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Cystidia]] of ''[[Melanoleuca communis]]'']]
[[File:Melanoleuca spore SEM.jpg|thumbnail|right|Spores of ''Melanoleuca'' in a [[scanning electron microscope]]]]
The spores of ''Melanoleuca'' are 7.0–11.0 x 4.0–6.0 [[micrometre|µm]], thin-walled, ellipsoid, amyloid with ornamented warts. They look very similar to the spores of ''[[Leucopaxillus]]'', however, ''Melanoleuca'' spores present a [[plage (mycology)|plage]]. [[Basidia]] are usually 4-spored, cylindrical to clavate. [[Pleurocystidia]] and [[cheilocystidia]] are present or absent, if present they are urticoid, thin-walled or fusiform to lageniform, thick-walled. They can have crystals incrusted at the apex. Cystidia are very important to separate species within this genus. [[Pileipellis]] is a trichoderm, sometimes a cutis. [[Hymenophore|Hymenophoral]] [[Trama (mycology)|trama]] parallel. [[Clamp connection]]s are absent in all parts of the fruit body.<ref name=Singer1986/><ref name=Bon1991/>

==Classification and phylogeny==
[[Molecular phylogenetics|Phylogenetic studies]] based on molecular characters have shown that ''Melanoleuca'' does not belong to the Tricholomataceae.<ref name=Moncalvo2002/><ref name=Matheny2006/> Moncalvo et al.<ref name=Moncalvo2002/> presented a [[Molecular phylogenetics|molecular phylogeny]] of the [[Agaricales]] based on [[ribosomal RNA|LSU ribosomal RNA]] sequence data, including sequences of ''[[Melanoleuca alboflavida|M. alboflavida]]'' and ''[[Melanoleuca cognata|M. cognata]]''. In this phylogeny ''Melanoleuca'' was clustered with ''Pluteus'' but with low [[bootstrapping|bootstrap support]]. 
Matheny et al.<ref name=Matheny2006/> performed a phylogenetic analysis of the Agaricales based on six-gene regions, including sequences of ''[[Melanoleuca verrucipes|M. verrucipes]]''. In this analysis ''Melanoleuca'', ''Pluteus'' and ''[[Volvariella]]'' were recovered as a [[monophyletic group]] and closely related with the aquatic [[gasteroid fungi|gasteromycete]] ''[[Limnoperdon]]''. These three genera together with members of the [[Amanitaceae]] and [[Pleurotaceae]] conformed the Pluteoid clade. Garnica et al.<ref name=Garnica2007/> and Binder et al.<ref name=Binder2010/> recovered a similar topology with ''Pluteus'', ''Volvariella'' and ''Melanoleuca'' as a monophyletic group. Justo et al. performed a molecular phylogeny of the family [[Pluteaceae]] and found ''Melanoleuca'' to be the [[sister group]] to a clade composed of ''Pluteus'' and ''[[Volvopluteus]]''.<ref name=Justo2011/> This clade was poorly supported in their analysis.<ref name=Justo2011/>

==Habitat and Distribution==
''Melanoleuca'' species are saprotrophic; growing on soil in [[grassland]]s, [[deciduous]] and [[evergreen forest]]s, and [[dune|sand dunes]].<ref name=Singer1986/><ref name=Boekhout1988/><ref name=Vesterholt2012/> They are [[cosmopolitan distribution|cosmopolitan]], but mainly distributed in [[temperate climate|temperate regions]]. Few species are known from the [[tropics]].<ref name=Singer1986/><ref name=Guzman1982/>

==Edibility==
''Melanoleuca'' species are reported to be edible. The most common species that are consumed are ''M. alboflavida'', ''M. cognata'', [[Melanoleuca evenosa|''M. evenosa'']], and [[Melanoleuca melaleuca|''M. melaleuca'']].<ref name=Singer1986/><ref name=Arora1986/><ref name=Bessette1996/> ''[[Melanoleuca strictipes]]'' is reported to be slightly toxic.<ref name=Vesterholt2012/>

==Species==
Murrill<ref name=Murrill1914/> published the description of 119 species from [[North America]], those species were revisited by Pfister<ref name=Pfister1984/> who concluded that only six belong in ''Melanoleuca'', while the rest belong to other genera as ''[[Clitocybe]]'' or ''[[Tricholoma]]''. Singer<ref name=Singer1986/> considered 48 species worldwide, while Bon<ref name=Bon1991/> recognized 65 species from [[Europe]]. Kirk et al.<ref name=Kirk2008/> consider about 50 species worldwide.

===Representative species===
*''[[Melanoleuca abutyracea]]'' (Cleland) Grgur. – Found in Australia
*''[[Melanoleuca alboflavida]]'' (Peck) Murrill with pileus pallid yellow brown to whitish. It is reported as edible.<ref name=Bessette1996/><ref name=Gillman1977/>
*''[[Melanoleuca brevipes]]'' (Bull.) Pat. is recognized by a short and relatively thick stipe, which looks out of proportion with the broad pileus.<ref name=Watling1998/>
*''[[Melanoleuca cinereifolia]]'' (Bon) Bon is found in sand dunes, among ''[[Ammophila (plant)|Ammophila]]''.<ref name=Vesterholt2012/>
*''[[Melanoleuca cognata]]'' (Fr.) Konrad & Maubl. pileus brown to ochre with gills showing a distinct ochre to pinkish color. It is reported to be edible.<ref name=Vesterholt2012/><ref name=Arora1986/>
*''[[Melanoleuca communis]]'' Sánchez-García & Cifuentes is a species described from [[Mexico]], found in [[pinophyta|coniferous]] or [[mixed forest]]s, morphologically similar to ''M. polioleuca''.<ref name=Sanchez2013/>
*''[[Melanoleuca evenosa]]'' (Sacc.) Konrad is a species usually found in coniferous forests, and often synonymized with ''M. subalpina'' and ''M. strictipes'', it has a whitish pileus and lageniform cystidia.<ref name=Vesterholt2012/> 
*''[[Melanoleuca excissa]]'' (Fr.) Singer with urticoid and septate cystidia, often with crystals at the apex.<ref name=Boekhout1988/>
*''[[Melanoleuca grammopodia]]''  (Bull.) Fayod has a relatively long stipe and urticoid cystidia.<ref name=Boekhout1988/>
*''[[Melanoleuca melaleuca]]'' (Pers.) Murrill has been a very controversial species; some authors recognize this taxon as having cystidia, while some recognized it as not having cystidia. Fontenla et al.<ref name=Fontenla2003/> put end to this discussion designating a neotype with cystidia.
*''[[Melanoleuca polioleuca]]'' (Fr.) Kühner & Maire has been incorrectly named ''M. melaleuca''. It has fusiform to lageniform cystidia.<ref name=Watling1998/>
*''[[Melanoleuca privernensis]]'' (consiglio, Contu, Setti & Vizzini) Consiglio, Setti & Vizzini is the only species that has [[amyloid (mycology)|inamyloid spores]].<ref name=Vizzini2010/> 
*''[[Melanoleuca tucumanensis]]'' Singer is a species described from [[Tafí del Valle]], [[Argentina]]<ref name=Singer1952/>
*''[[Melanoleuca verrucipes]]'' (Fr.) Singer is easy to recognize by a blackish dotted stipe.<ref name=Boekhout1988/>
*''[[Melanoleuca yucatanensis]]'' Guzman & Bon is a species described from tropical forests in Mexico, it has urticoid cystidia without apical crystals <ref name=Guzman1982/>
